( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Nipunaarachchi) (1) :

asked the Minister of Urban Development and Sacred Area Development,: (a) Is he aware that a sum of 1230 million rupees had been allocated from the revised budget of the year 2007 (as mentioned in the Budget estimates of 2008) for environmental and community development projects in the Lunawa area? (b) Will he inform this House (i) the amount of money that was spent in the year 2007 for the purpose mentioned above; and (ii) the projects for which this amount was spent?
(c) If not, why?

R.M. DILANI RATHNAYAKA : POST OF SUB POST MASTER
( ) (The Hon. Ranjith Aluvihare) , (1) :
asked the Minister of Posts and Telecommunication,
(a) Is he aware that a person by the name of R.M. Dilani Rathnayaka of No.87/3, Denida, Nawalapitiya is employed as a full time registered substitute of the Denida Sub Post Office since 30.09.2003?

(b) Will he inform this House the reason for not appointing Dilani Rathnayaka to the aforesaid post, which fell vacant as a result of the Sub Post Mistress of Denida Sub Post Office being promoted with effect from 31.07.2006, as appointing the permanent substitute to the aforesaid vacancy is the usual practice?

(c) However, will he admit that appointing a person by the name of Sisira Kumara Bandara who has not even served as a substitute of the aforesaid Sub Post Office, to the aforesaid vacancy with effect from 15.09.2007, is not fair?
(d) Will he state whether the person by the name of Dilani Rathnayaka will be appointed to the post of Sub Post Master of Denida Sub Post Office on the basis of qualifications and experience?
(e) If not, why?

Sir, I rise to a point of Order. This is very unfair. When the Hon. Ministers are not present in the House we cannot expect the Chief Government Whip to answer these questions which are of very technical nature. The Hon. Minister, in charge of the subject must answer. I have been the Minister in charge of this subject. I know that there are several questions raised by these Hon. Members. But the Hon. Minister in charge of the subject never comes. There must be some practice. ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena) , .

. . . - [Interruption-] you should not - ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) , . ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena) . ? . ? . I agree with you on the principle. But you should not interpret the principle that it the Minister in charge of the subject was here that he would be able to answer any question. ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem) Yes, true. [Interruption.] ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena)
No, that is a right of an MP. I agree on that. I agree with you on the principle. ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem)
I am not blaming, you Minister. ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena)
No, you can blame me. What I am trying to say is, do not interpret to say that if the Minister was present that he could have answered any question. ( ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem)
At least you - [Interruption.] ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena)
So, I gave the assurance to the Hon. Member that this matter will be brought to the notice of the Hon. Minister. That is all [Interruption.] ( ) (The Hon. Anura Dissanayake) , 65,610 ,

asked the Minister of Transport: (a) Is he aware that (i) Mr. R. G. Wimalasooriya residing at No. 158/1, Polduwa, Batapola, served at Galle Depot of the Ceylon Transport Board from 01 Mach 1978; and
(ii) he was sent on retirement on 25 March 2006 upon reaching the age of 53 years?

(b) Will he inform this House the reason for sending this person, who requested an extension of service, as there was an opportunity for him to get his service extended up to the age of 57 years according to Public Administration Circular No. 5/2002 and dated 23.08.2002 on retirement?
(c) Will he state,
(i) whether he will be given an extension to service to serve until 57 years of age] and
(ii) whether steps will be taken to provide him with the salaries and allowances in arrears for the period during which he was subjected to injustice?
(d) If not, why?

. . : MRS. H. S. WICKRAMARACHCHI : EXTENSION OF SERVICE 0367/08 9.

asked the Minister of Finance and Planning,: (a) Is he aware that (i) Mrs. H.S. Wickramarachchi of No.13/11A, Kalidasa Rd., Matara served as the confidential Secretary of the Regional Head office of the Peoples Bank at Matara; (ii) she has been sent on retirement with effect from 14.10.2007; and (iii) she has requested an extension of service from 14.10.2007 to 14.10.2008 under the provisions of the employee circular No. 323/2001? (b) Will he inform this House (i) her period of service in the bank; (ii) the date of her annual increment; (iii) the number of privilege leave and the number of days of sick leave she has saved; and (iv) the reason for sending her on retirement with effect from 14.10.2007 even without allowing her to reach her next increment date though she had asked for an extension of service?

(c) Will he take necessary action to grant her the due extension of service and pay the salaries and other allowances for the period during which she was subjected to the aforesaid injustice? (d) If not, why?

: LAND UNDER FOREST CONSERVATION DEPARTMENT IN KOTHALAWALA : STEPS TO PROTECT
( ) (The Hon. Thilakaratne Withanachchi) - (1) :
(ii) ;

(iii) ,
(iv) ,

asked the Minister of Environment and Natural Resources, :
(a) Will he inform this House

(i) whether the boundaries of the lands belonging to the Forest Conservation Department and situated in the Kothalawala area adjoining the 750 acre lands and bordering the Kannaliya Forest Reserve in Nagoda Divisional Secretarys Division in Galle, have been surveyed and demarcated;
(ii) if so, the year in which it was done;

(iii) if there are private lands bordering the forest reserve, the names of those lands; (iv) the extent of those lands; (v) whether an unlawful acquisition of the aforesaid lands has taken place after the demarcation of boundaries; (vi) if so, whether the persons who have acquired lands as mentioned above have been identified and legal steps have been taken against them; and (vii) the names of those persons? (b) Is he aware that these lands that must be maintained as forest reserves belonging to the Government, are being acquired by large-scale land owners even at present? (c) Will he state the steps that have been taken so far to protect the valuable forest resource which belongs to the Government? (d) If not, why?

(b) Will he inform this House (i) the number of persons who have passed out from these medical colleges as graduates or diploma holders since 1990; (ii) whether the intake of students to these Indigenous Medical Colleges was based on the national requirement or else the limited space available in them; and (iii) the number of graduates produced by the above Medical Colleges in 2007? (c) If not, why?

MR. M. A. S. SHANTHA : PROMOTION 0669/08 13.
? () . ? () , ? asked the Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Administration, and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order, :

(a) Is he aware that Mr. M.A.S. Shantha (Police Constable 31746) of Nawagattegama, No.40, Weliwewa joined the Police Service as a Police Constable of the Regular Service from 15.06.1989? (b) Will he inform this House

(i) the reasons for the cancellation of his appointment while he was undergoing training at the Wennappuwa Police Training School; (ii) whether he was reinstated in service with effect from 10.04.1992 as the cancellation of his previous appointment was unjustifiable; and (iii) the reason for demoting the aforesaid person, who was promoted to the post of Police Sergeant with effect from 23.02.2006 on the decision of granting promotions to the persons who have not received promotions in the Police Service for more than 16 years which was made on an order given by His Excellency the President, with the aforesaid demotion being effective from 16.04.2006? (c) Will he submit to this House (i) whether there is a breach of discipline or any charge leveled against Mr. Shantha; and (ii) the reason for counting his period of service from 01.08.1992 when granting the aforesaid promotion, despite the fact that his appointment has been approved by the Police Department from 15.06.1989?
(d) Will he take necessary action to cause justice to Mr. Shantha? (e) If not, why?

AARACHCHIKATTUWA DIVISIONAL SECRETARYS DIVISION : TANKS 0671/08 14. ( ) (The Hon. Samansiri Herath) (1) : () (i) ; (ii) ; (iii) ; (iv) ; (v) , ; (vi) , ; ? () (i) ; (ii) ;
() , ? asked the Minister of Irrigation and Water Management and Minister of Ports and Aviation, :

(a) Will he inform this House (i) separately, the total number of tanks that belong to the categories of minor irrigations and major irrigations in the Aarachchikattuwa Divisional Secretariat Division; (ii) separately, the extent of reservations of the aforesaid tanks; (iii) the year in which the surveys have been carried out for the last time for the purpose of identifying the aforesaid reservations; (iv) whether there are occupants in the aforesaid reservations; (v) if there are occupants, whether they occupy the aforesaid reservations on any legal basis; and (vi) the relevant year, the basis and the duration of their occupation?

(b) Will he submit to this House (i) separately, the names and addresses of the persons occupying the aforesaid reservations in respect of minor irrigations and major irrigations; (ii) whether alternative lands have been identified for the distribution to the aforesaid occupants of the reservations of tanks; (iii) if so, the locations of those lands; and (iv) if alternative lands have not been identified, the date on which action will be taken to grant them? (c) If not, why?

This year is significant in the context of urbanisation in South Asia for two reasons. First, it marks 60 years since the countries of India, Pakistan and Sri Lanka came into existence as modern nation states. Second, it is a watershed in human history when, for the first time, more than half of humanity, about 3.3 billion people, now live in towns and cities. In South Asia, home to over 1.6 billion people, a quarter of humanity, a third lives in urban areas. As the world becomes increasingly urban, the centre of gravity of this process is gradually moving to South Asia and China. According to the United Nations projections, within seven years time, that is, by 2015, South Asia will account for five of the worlds 12 biggest urban agglomerations (cities with more than 15 million people), namely, Mumbai, Delhi, Kolkata, Dhaka and Karachi. Further, all but two of these 12 mega cities (Tokyo and New York- Newark) will be located in developing countries. In all, by 2015, over 540 million South Asians will live in towns and cities and, by the year 2030, this figure will cross 813 million. These are colossal numbers by any yardstick. To put these numbers in perspective, global population is projected at 8.2 billion in 2030 of which 4.9 billion will be
* . . Produced at end of speech.

urban dwellers. And 3.9 billion will live in less developed regions. In other words, by the year 2030, one in five urban dwellers will be a South Asian. This broad brush picture, of course, conceals marked differences in the process and nature of urbanisation within South Asia. To begin with, the levels of urbanisation vary significantly across countries." , . I quote again: While Pakistan is the most urbanised country in the region at 36 percent, Bhutan, Sri Lanka and Nepal are among the least urbanised (12, 15 and 17 percent respectively). It is interesting to note, in particular, the low level of urbanisation in Sri Lanka, given its relatively high per capita income and human development report scores vis--vis the other countries in South Asia. In Sri Lanka, based on materials of construction used for wall, floor and roof, housing units have been divided into three types viz; Permanent, Semi-Permanent and Improvised. Out of occupied housing units in 18 districts, 69.8 per cent are permanent, 28.3 per cent are semi-permanent and 0.9 per cent are improvised. , . , . . , . . . " " . , .

Hon. Presiding Member, while discussing the important pieces of legislation that the two Hon. Ministers have presented in this House, I would like to divert for a moment to refer to the situation in the Weligama area. Unfortunately, for the last three days continuously there has been a tense climate prevailing in Weligama and the outskirts of the town. On the night of the 21st Sunday, a gang of people who had gone into a hotel, had an argument over paying a bill and had damaged that hotel and some of the items in the hotel, following which the police intervened and three people were arrested. They were made to compensate the hotel owner by paying Rs. 2000. Then, after going back to their village, they have come back and engaged in damaging and attacking a place of worship, a mosque, particularly the Meera Jumma Mosque in the Weligama town. Now these sorts of incidents are happening far too often to our liking. The Government particularly has to take a serious note of these incidents targeting places of religious worship. Though a curfew has been clamped, even now the security of the Muslim people in that area is in serious jeopardy. Last night too a gramasevaka officer from Welipitiya area in Weligama was mercilessly attacked by gangs of thugs in the surrounding villages and he is presently warded in the hospital. He has been hospitalized after being severely beaten up. This being the Ramadan period, obviously Muslims are terribly perturbed and I must say here that the people of the area are blaming the police for not taking timely action. Several complaints have been made about assaults. There have been some teachers who have been assaulted, a few other members of the public have been assaulted and this is happening regularly. The day before yesterday, in Koledanda, another village, a mosque was sought to be attacked and since people intervened, they were somewhat able to prevent it but yet the tense situation is prevailing. I hope the Government will take serious note of these incidents and timely action and instruct the police to arrest the culprits. They are showing some reluctance to arrest the culprits and therefore these people are having a sense of impunity, a sense of immunity and that is why they are going ahead and attacking places of worship. This situation should be contained immediately. Even a Muezzin of this particular mosque in Koledanda has been attacked and this has been carried out by the police. Therefore, people are losing confidence in the very people who should maintain law and order and enforce law to prevent crimes in this country. This situation in Weligama should not be allowed to continue and as a matter of interest there was another issue that we came to know. On the very day, a petrol shed belonging to the Chairman of the Weligama

Urban Council, Mr. Hussain Mohamed, who happens to be a Muslim - he is also from the governing party, the UPFA - was totally destroyed. I am told that the loss is in the region of Rupees three to four million and I have reliable information that a particular Minister of the Provincial Council of the Southern Province who had a political vendetta has used this situation of communal disturbance to destroy and cause damage to the petrol shed of the Chairman of the Weligama Urban Council. Today, he is a very distraught man. Though he is a Member belonging to the Government - he belongs to the ruling party of the Weligama Urban Council - his own petrol shed has been destroyed and the popular suspicion is that a particular Minister of the Southern Provincial Council has been behind this attack. There are various connotations. There are elements taking advantage of a situation and are also willing to do harm to their political opponents and destroy their properties. These matters must be placed on record so that the Government will ensure that at least in the future such incidents do not take place. As a matter of practice, it has been observed in many places that the police always close the door of the stable after the horses have bolted. They step into the area after the event has taken place. Timely action is always delayed. Though the incident occurred on Sunday night, until Monday, no curfew was imposed. Curfew was imposed only on Monday night and that too from 10.00 p.m. to 6.00 a.m. I am sure it will be imposed even for a few more days so that the situation could be brought under some semblance of control. The request of the people of the area is that there should be continuous heavy surveillance by the security forces and the police to see that further incidents do not occur in this area. With those comments, Mr. Presiding Member, I will move on to say a few words in Tamil since the Fair Minister of the Ministry of Housing and Common Amenities who too comes from the Ampara District is here. There are specific issues concerning the Ampara District which have been in a state of neglect for quite some time. These are issues which we have collectively agitated for but still not materialized. Therefore, I thought that I should refer to these so that matters would be expedited. , 2004 , . , , . -

Of course, there is a delay in the construction of the houses, but nothing has been interrupted. It is going on. There is a definite delay on account of lands not being available in that area. But, we will definitely look into it. There is no question of those people having to go on protest because we will take care of their immediate needs.
